articles.title: Rare Saturn-sized rogue planet is first to have its mass measured
articles.summary: Researchers have confirmed the mass of a free-floating planet thanks to a lucky convergence of ground- and space-based telescopes
articles.content:
Researchers have confirmed the mass of a free-floating planet thanks to a lucky convergence of ground- and space-based telescopes

Artist’s impression of the free-floating planet lensing light from a distant source J. Skowron/OGLE

Nearly 10,000 light years away, a planet the size of Saturn is floating all on its own through empty space. In a stroke of luck, researchers were able to spot this strange, dark world using both ground-based telescopes and the Gaia space telescope, allowing them to measure the mass of a free-floating, or rogue, exoplanet for the first time.

Most rogue worlds that have been found are either more massive than Jupiter or lighter than Neptune, leaving in the middle a gap in size that researchers refer to as the “Einstein desert”. This has generally been attributed to the idea that lighter-than-Neptune worlds are relatively easy to eject from pre-existing orbits around stars, whereas planets more massive than Jupiter don’t have to form inside traditional planetary systems, but can sometimes form similarly to stars in free space.

Advertisement

That makes this newfound planet particularly rare. It has two names – KMT-2024-BLG-0792 and OGLE-2024-BLG-0516 – because Andrzej Udalski at the University of Warsaw in Poland and his colleagues spotted it independently with two different ground-based telescopes. But what’s even more unusual is the fact that they were able to measure its mass at about one-fifth that of Jupiter.

“What’s really great about this one is that it’s the first one that we’ve got that has a mass measurement, and that was only possible because they got Gaia observations as well as Earth-based observations,” says Gavin Coleman at Queen Mary University of London. The researchers found this planet through a method called gravitational microlensing, which occurs when the light from a bright, distant object is bent by a planet’s gravitational pull, creating a sort of halo around the planet. That’s where the researchers got lucky: when the microlensing event was spotted from the ground, the Gaia space telescope happened to be pointed in the right direction, so it captured the event too.

“Mass is the main parameter deciding on the classification as a planet,” says Udalski, so that makes this technically the first confirmed free-floating rogue planet. “This is the moment from which we may be sure that the candidate is a real planet, and free-floating planets indeed exist,” he says. NASA’s Nancy Grace Roman space telescope, planned to launch in 2027, is expected to find many more, though.

“They should be very numerous and they may be crucial for our understanding of the processes during the formation of planetary systems, as the majority of them are ejected from planetary systems at the early formation stages,” says Udalski. That includes our own solar system, which some research hints may have ejected a planet in its early days.

articles.personality_title: Scientists measure mass of rare free-floating planet for the first time
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Scientists study planets that orbit stars, but some planets float alone in space without a star. These are called rogue or free-floating planets. Until now, measuring the mass of these lonely planets has been very hard.

**What happened** – Researchers spotted a planet about the size of Saturn, drifting alone nearly 10,000 light years away. They used both ground telescopes and the Gaia space telescope at the same time to observe a special event called gravitational microlensing. This happens when the planet’s gravity bends light from a distant star, letting scientists measure the planet’s mass. This is the first time they have measured the mass of a free-floating planet.

**Impact** – This planet is unusual because it fits into a size range where planets were rarely found before, called the “Einstein desert.” Measuring its mass confirms it is truly a planet, not a star or another object. This helps scientists understand how planets form and move, especially those that get thrown out of their solar systems early on. It also shows that these rogue planets really exist.

**What's next step** – In 2027, NASA will launch the Nancy Grace Roman space telescope, which is expected to find many more free-floating planets. These new discoveries will help scientists learn more about how planets form and how common rogue planets are in our galaxy.

**One-sentence takeaway** – For the first time, astronomers have measured the mass of a rare free-floating planet, opening new doors to understanding planets that drift alone in space.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les scientifiques mesurent pour la première fois la masse d’une planète errante rare
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les scientifiques étudient des planètes qui tournent autour d’étoiles, mais certaines planètes flottent seules dans l’espace sans étoile. On les appelle des planètes errantes ou libres. Jusqu’à présent, mesurer la masse de ces planètes solitaires était très difficile.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs ont repéré une planète de la taille de Saturne, flottant seule à presque 10 000 années-lumière. Ils ont utilisé à la fois des télescopes terrestres et le télescope spatial Gaia pour observer un phénomène spécial appelé microlentille gravitationnelle. Cela se produit quand la gravité de la planète dévie la lumière d’une étoile lointaine, ce qui permet aux scientifiques de mesurer la masse de la planète. C’est la première fois qu’ils mesurent la masse d’une planète errante.

**Impact** – Cette planète est inhabituelle car elle se trouve dans une gamme de tailles où l’on trouvait rarement des planètes, appelée le « désert d’Einstein ». Mesurer sa masse confirme qu’il s’agit bien d’une planète, et non d’une étoile ou d’un autre objet. Cela aide les scientifiques à comprendre comment les planètes se forment et se déplacent, surtout celles qui sont expulsées de leur système solaire tôt dans leur histoire. Cela prouve aussi que ces planètes errantes existent vraiment.

**Prochaine étape** – En 2027, la NASA lancera le télescope spatial Nancy Grace Roman, qui devrait découvrir beaucoup plus de planètes errantes. Ces nouvelles découvertes aideront les scientifiques à mieux comprendre la formation des planètes et la fréquence des planètes errantes dans notre galaxie.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Pour la première fois, des astronomes ont mesuré la masse d’une planète errante rare, ouvrant de nouvelles voies pour comprendre les planètes qui flottent seules dans l’espace.
articles.personality_title_es: Científicos miden por primera vez la masa de un raro planeta errante
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Los científicos estudian planetas que giran alrededor de estrellas, pero algunos planetas flotan solos en el espacio sin una estrella. A estos se les llama planetas errantes o libres. Hasta ahora, medir la masa de estos planetas solitarios ha sido muy difícil.

**Qué pasó** – Investigadores detectaron un planeta del tamaño de Saturno, flotando solo a casi 10,000 años luz de distancia. Usaron telescopios en la Tierra y el telescopio espacial Gaia al mismo tiempo para observar un evento especial llamado microlente gravitacional. Esto ocurre cuando la gravedad del planeta dobla la luz de una estrella distante, permitiendo a los científicos medir la masa del planeta. Es la primera vez que miden la masa de un planeta errante.

**Impacto** – Este planeta es raro porque está en un rango de tamaño donde antes se encontraban pocos planetas, llamado el “desierto de Einstein”. Medir su masa confirma que es realmente un planeta, no una estrella u otro objeto. Esto ayuda a los científicos a entender cómo se forman y se mueven los planetas, especialmente los que son expulsados de sus sistemas solares temprano. También demuestra que estos planetas errantes existen.

**Próximos pasos** – En 2027, la NASA lanzará el telescopio espacial Nancy Grace Roman, que se espera que encuentre muchos más planetas errantes. Estos nuevos hallazgos ayudarán a entender mejor cómo se forman los planetas y cuántos planetas errantes hay en nuestra galaxia.

**Resumen en una frase** – Por primera vez, los astrónomos midieron la masa de un raro planeta errante, abriendo nuevas posibilidades para entender los planetas que flotan solos en el espacio.
